Indicates whether the model offers advanced controls and increased functionality such as sending notifications when the refrigerator door doesn't close or allowing for a service center to remotely diagnose problems. Refrigerators with connected functionality are smart grid ready; if linked with your energy provider or an energy management system these products can dynamically adjust their energy use, potentially lowering your electric bill.
This refrigerator design is approximately 24 inches deep without the door, making them nearly flush with standard kitchen cabinets. With the doors, they are generally 27-29 inches deep.
Built-in refrigerators are designed to be installed totally encased by kitchen cabinets.
Classification of products by the type of energy used or by capacity or other performance-related features that affect efficiency. Different ENERGY STAR levels may apply to different product classes.
This is the type of defrost function. Automatic, manual, and partial automatic are the standard defrost types.
Designation for refrigerators, refrigerator-freezers, and freezers with a total volume of less than 7.75 cubic feet and 36 inches or less in height.
Allows access to ice and/or water through an exterior dispenser. Automatic icemakers and through the door dispensers offer convenience but they can increase energy use by 14-20%.
This shows the configuration of the refrigerator.
The total interior volume of the refrigerator, including both the refrigerator and freezer compartments. Generally, the larger the refrigerator, the greater the energy consumption.
Provides guidance about what you need in your home to enable connected capabilities like smart phone control, e.g. ‘WiFi’ or Zigbee.
Included in some refrigerators for making ice cubes.

The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.
The date that the model is available for purchase.
Height to vent is the distance from the bottom of the water heater's tank to its vent.
Tank height is the distance from the bottom of the water heater's tank to the top of its tank.

This column includes for the certified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a  product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of
seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification
information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will
have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information
on certified models in their information systems.
Tank diameter is the width or diameter of the water heater’s tank.
Therms/year refers to the amount of natural gas consumed by the water heater according to its Energy Factor determined by the DOE test procedure, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 10, Section 430
A distinguishing identifier, usually alphanumeric, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler.
The type of vent used by the water heater: Atmospheric Vent, Direct Vent, or Power Vent.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
Fuel type refers to the kind of fuel that the water heater uses to heat the water, either natural gas or propane for gas-fired water heaters, or electric for heat pump water heaters.
Input refers to the burner size of the gas-fired water heater, in thousand BTU per hour.
The amount of water contained in the water heater measured in gallons. Some tankless water heaters do not have a storage volume.
Vent size 2 is the width or diameter of a second vent opening.

Energy Factor is the ratio of useful energy output from the water heater to the total amount of energy delivered to the water heater. EF is a metric used to compare relative efficiencies of water heaters. The higher the EF is, the more efficient the water heater. EF is determined by the DOE test procedure, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 10, Section 430.
This field is used to indicate the type of qualified product: Gas Storage Water Heater, Gas Storage-type Tankless Water Heater, Gas Tankless Water Heater, or Electric Heat Pump Water Heater.
The average hourly energy, expressed in Btu/hr, required to maintain the stored water temperature.
Vent size is the width or diameter of the vent opening.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR certified products.
The ratio of the heat transferred to the water flowing through the water heater to the amount of energy consumed by the water heater.

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Water Heaters
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 3.2 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Water Heaters that are effective April 16, 2015. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at https://www.energystar.gov/products/water_heaters/residential_water_heaters_key_product_criteria
columns_name: Recovery Efficiency per UEF test method (%)
Maximum Gallons Per Minute over 67°F rise
Gallons/year at 125°F outlet temp for Propane
Minimum Gallons Per Minute over 67°F rise
Therms Per Year at 125°F outlet temp
First Hour Rating at 125°F outlet temp (gallons/hr)
columns_description: The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.
The water heater's depth, in inches.
Refers to the total area consumed by the solar collector.

Forced Circulation systems use a pump to circulate the water or other fluid from the collector where it is heated by the sun to the storage tank. Integral Collector Storage (ICS) systems, or “batch” water heaters, combine the collector and the storage tank into one. Thermosyphon systems have a separate storage tank, located above the collector. Liquid (which could be water or an antifreeze solution) warmed in the collector rises to the storage tank.
Recovery efficiency refers to how efficiently the heat from the burner is transferred to the water in the tank per the UEF test method.
The amount of hot water, in gallons, a tankless water heater can supply per minute over a 67°F rise per the UEF test method. This value is calculated for products that do not display UEF data.
Gallons/year refers to the amount of propane consumed by the water heater with a tested outlet temperature of 125°F per the UEF test method.

Uniform Energy Factor (UEF) is the newest measure of water heater overall efficiency. It is a metric used to compare the relative efficiencies of water heaters. The higher the UEF is, the more efficient the water heater.
Tank diameter is the width or diameter of the water heater’s tank.
Tank height is the distance from the bottom of the water heater’s tank to the top of its tank.
The type of vent used by the water heater: Atmospheric Vent, Direct Vent, or Power Vent.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information on certified models in their information systems.
The amount of hot water, in gallons, a tankless water heater can supply per minute over a 67°F rise per the UEF test method.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

Solar Energy Factor refers to the energy delivered by the total system divided by the electrical or gas energy put into the system. The higher the SEF, the greater the solar contribution to water heating, which reduces the energy required by the backup water heater. The SEF is presented as a number similar to the Energy Factor (EF) given to conventional water heaters by the DOE test procedure.
Vent size 2 is the width or diameter of a second vent opening.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned by EPA.
The date that the model is available for purchase.

Solar Water Heaters are available in the following collector types: batch, flat-plate, and evacuated tube. Batch collectors heat water in dark tanks or tubes within an insulated box, storing the water until drawn. Flat-plate collectors consist of copper tubes fitted to flat absorber plates. Evacuated tubes contain a vacuum of space around the metal or glass tube.
Therms/year refers to the amount of natural gas consumed by the water heater with a tested outlet temperature of 125°F per the UEF test method.
kWh/year, kilowatt hours per year, refers to the amount of electricity consumed by the water heater according to its Uniform Energy Factor
A distinguishing identifier, usually alphanumeric, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler.
The water heater's height, in inches.
First Hour Rating is the amount of hot water (in gallons) a storage water heater can supply per hour (starting with a tank full of hot water) per the UEF test method.
This field is used to indicate whether the backup to the solar system is a tank or is tankless.
Input refers to the burner size of the water heater, in BTU per hour.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.
Auxiliary Input refers to the input BTU per hour rating of the backup gas water heater in the solar system, in thousand BTU per hour.
The limit to the system’s tolerance of freezing weather conditions.

This field is used to indicate the type of qualified product: Gas Storage Water Heater, Gas Tankless Water Heater, Heat Pump Water Heater, High Capacity Storage, Solar with Gas Backup, or Solar with Electric Backup.

Volts refer to the potential of an outlet or circuit to provide electrical energy. The standard current in the typical U.S. home is in the range of 110 to 120 volts. However, circuits used for equipment, such as heat pump water heaters, may use voltage in the range of 220 to 240 volts. These heavy-duty circuits can be identified by their non-standard outlet plugs.
Electric Input kW refers to the input wattage of the heat pump or supplementary electric elements.
Volume is the capacity of the tank in a solar system, in gallons.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
The water heater's width, in inches.
Capacity of the tank, in gallons.
Fuel type refers the kind of fuel the water heater uses to heat the water, either natural gas or propane.
Electric Input kW refers to the input wattage of the heat pump or supplementary electric elements.
Height to vent is the distance from the bottom of the water heater’s tank to its vent.
Volume is the capacity of the tank, in gallons. Storage Volume is not applicable for gas tankless, solar with gas backup, or solar with electric backup water heaters.
Vent size is the width or diameter of the vent opening.

columns_description: A low power mode that the computer enters automatically after a period of inactivity or by manual selection. A computer with Sleep capability can quickly "wake" in response to network connections or user interface devices with a latency of less than or equal to 5 seconds from initiation of wake event to system becoming fully usable including rendering of display.
Typical energy consumption of a model.

The power state in which the operating system and other software have completed loading, a user profile has been created, activity is limited to those basic applications that the system starts by default, and the computer is not in Sleep Mode. Furthermore, the Computer has reached an Idle condition and the Display has entered a low-power state.

The lowest power mode which cannot be switched off (influenced) by the user and that may persist for an indefinite time when the appliance is connected to the main electricity supply and used in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions. A second-order classification or sub-type within a product type that is based on product features and installed components. Product categories are used in this specification to determine qualification and test requirements. TEC (Typical Energy Consumption) is a method of testing and comparing the energy performance of computers, which focuses on the typical electricity consumed by a product while in normal operation during a representative period of time.)

Desktop: A computer whose main unit is designed to be located in a permanent location, often on a desk or on the floor. Desktop computers are not designed for portability and are designed for use with an external display, keyboard, and mouse.

Integrated Computer: A desktop computer in which the computing hardware and display are integrated into a single housing, and which is connected to ac mains power through a single cable. Integrated desktop computers come in one of two possible forms: (1) a system where the display and computer are physically combined into a single unit; or (2) a system packaged as a single system where the display is separate but is connected to the main chassis by a dc power cord and both the computer and display are powered from a single power supply.

Notebook: A computer designed specifically for portability and to be operated for extended periods of time both with and without a direct connection to an ac mains power source.

Slate/tablet: A computing device designed for portability.

Portable All-in-one Computer: A computing device designed for limited portability.

Small-scale Server: A computer that typically uses desktop components in a desktop form factor, but is designed primarily to be a storage host for other computers. Small-scale Servers are designed to perform functions such as providing network infrastructure services (e.g., archiving) and hosting data/media.

Thin Client: An independently-powered computer that relies on a connection to remote computing resources to obtain primary functionality. Main computing functions (e.g., program execution, data storage, interaction with other Internet resources) are provided by the remote computing resources.

Workstation: A high-performance, single-user computer typically used for graphics, CAD, software development, financial and scientific applications among other compute intensive tasks.

Furthermore, the Computer has reached an Idle condition and the Display has entered a low-power state.

The lowest power mode which cannot be switched off (influenced) by the user and that may persist for an indefinite time when the appliance is connected to the main electricity supply and used in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions.
The default power-saving mode used by the computer.

A low power mode that the computer enters automatically after a period of inactivity or by manual selection. A computer with Sleep capability can quickly "wake" in response to network connections or user interface devices with a latency of less than or equal to 5 seconds from initiation of wake event to system becoming fully usable including rendering of display.

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Commercial Steam Cookers
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 1.2 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Commercial Steam Cookers that are effective as of August 1, 2003. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at  https://www.energystar.gov/products/commercial_food_service_equipment/commercial_steam_cookers/key_product_criteria
columns_description:
The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of
seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification
information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will
have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information
on certified models in their information systems.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
A distinguishing identifier, usually alphanumeric, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler.

An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. This column includes alternative means to identify the model/model family (e.g., additional model names, additional model numbers, retailer SKUs, product descriptions).
The type of steamer (e.g., pressure, pressureless).
Different technology options (e.g., boiler, boilerless, or steam generator).
The maximum number of full-size steam pans the steam cooker can accept in accordance with the heavy-load cooking test.
The type of fuel used (e.g., gas, electric).
The quantity of energy input to the food products; expressed as a percentage of the quantity of energy input to the appliance during the heavy-, medium-, and light-load tests.
The average water consumption during heavy-load cooking as expressed in gallons per hour (GPH).
The rate of appliance energy consumption while it is maintaining or holding at a stabilized operating condition or temperature measured in Btu/h.
The rate of appliance energy consumption while it is maintaining or holding at a stabilized operating condition or temperature measured in watts.
The date that the model is available for purchase.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification
bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance
characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it
is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of
characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned
by EPA.

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Commercial Griddles
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 1.2 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Commercial Griddles that are effective as of May 8, 2009 or January 1, 2011. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at https://www.energystar.gov/products/commercial_food_service_equipment/commercial_griddles/key_products_criteria.
columns_description:

seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification
information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will
have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information
on certified models in their information systems.

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a  product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.

Designates whether the model is a single-sided or double-sided commercial griddle. A double-sided griddle has hinged upper griddle plates (platens) that swing down over the food, thereby cooking the food from both sides at once.
Designates the fuel type used by the commercial griddle. Qualified commercial griddle models are either gas or electric.
This column designates whether the model was tested in the single-sided or double-sided configuration.
This field provides additional details as to the type of griddle plate used (e.g., polished steel or chrome ½-inch grooved plate).

Designates the width of the griddle in ft. For qualification of a product family, the 3 ft. model within the product family can serve as the representative model. (If product family includes units smaller than 3 ft.; however, each additional unit shall be tested and qualified separately from its product family.)
Designates the depth of the griddle in ft.
Represents the surface area of the commercial griddle (width multiplied by the depth).
The ratio of energy absorbed by the food product to the total energy supplied to the griddle during cooking.

The maximum production rate of the griddle while cooking a specified food product in accordance with the heavy-load cooking-energy efficiency test, expressed in pounds per hour. The production rate is the average rate at which the griddle brings a specified food product to a specified final temperature.

For gas griddles, this field expresses the rate of  griddle energy consumption while it is maintaining or holding at a stabilized operating condition or temperature. The idle rate is normalized based on the area of the (bottom) cooking surface.

For electric griddles, this field expresses the rate of  griddle energy consumption while it is maintaining or holding at a stabilized operating condition or temperature. The idle rate is normalized based on the area of the (bottom) cooking surface.
This field demonstrates whether the product has integrated or add-on top platens. This impacts the testing of the models as single- or double-sided.
The date that the model is available for purchase.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification
bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance
characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it
is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of
characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned
by EPA.

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Most Efficient Ventilating Fans
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 4.0 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Ventilating Fans that are effective as of October 1, 2015. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at http://www.energystar.gov/index.cfm?c=vent_fans.pr_crit_vent_fans
columns_name: Energy Efficiency - Measured Outside the Fixture (lm/W)
Meets ENERGY STAR Most Efficient 2019 Criteria
columns_description: The date that the model is available for purchase.

The quotient of the total luminous flux (lumens) emitted by the fixture over the total power input (Watts). It is expressed in lumens per watt (lm/W). For ENERGY STAR qualified fixtures this applies to light fixtures that are considered directional and are measured at the fixture level. This includes the following residential grade directional fixture types: line-voltage track lights, ceiling fan light kits, undercabinet and cove lighting, downlights, recessed, pendant or surface mounted and includes retrofit kits for existing recessed cans. This also includes the following LIMITED commercial fixture types: Accent lights such as line-voltage track lights, under cabinet task lights, portable desk task lights, downlights, recessed, pendant or surface-mounts BUT EXCLUDES typical commercial and industrial fixtures such as recessed troffers or linear forms (e.g. linear fluorescent pendants) typically used in office spaces.

Efficacy is calculated by using airflow and fan motor electrical power values as tested per the requirements of this specification. Fan motor electrical usage is the only energy consumption considered for the fan efficacy calculation. Energy used for other fan auxiliaries (e.g., lights, sensors, heaters, timers, or night lights) is not included in the determination of fan efficacy.

It is standard industry practice to round down airflow to the nearest 10 cfm when publishing this metric in product directories as the Airflow Certified Rating. For this reason, Airflow Certified Rating and As-Tested Airflow may occasionally differ on this list. In the case of a range hood, Airflow Certified Rating represents performance at working speed, while in the case of a bathroom or utility room fan, or an in-line ventilating fan, it represents maximum speed.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance

For this reason, Airflow Certified Rating and As-Tested Airflow may occasionally differ on this list. In the case of a range hood, Airflow Certified Rating represents performance at working speed, while in the case of a bathroom or utility room fan, or an in-line ventilating fan, it represents maximum speed.

Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.

The expected useful life of the light source. Measured differently depending on the technology of the light source. For example, LED lighting expected useful life is based on the estimated point at which only 70% of the original light output remains, while for older technologies, like fluorescent and halogen, estimated useful life is based on the measured median sample life.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of
seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification
information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will
have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information
on certified models in their information systems.

It is standard industry practice to round down airflow to the nearest 10 cfm when publishing this metric in product directories as the Airflow Certified Rating. For this reason, Airflow Certified Rating and As-Tested Airflow may occasionally differ on this list. In the case of a range hood, Airflow Certified Rating represents performance at working speed, while in the case of a bathroom or utility room fan, or an in-line ventilating fan, it represents maximum speed.

A description of the "color" of a light source measured on the Kelvin (K) scale. CFLs are available in a range of color temperatures. Lower values (2700-3000K) mean the white light has a warmer (red-yellow) tone, while higher kelvin (4100-6500K) mean the white light has a cooler (bluer) tone.
Total power consumed by the luminaire while in use.

The amount of light emitted by the light source or light fixture. Non directional fixtures (with removable light sources i.e. GU24 base bulbs) are measured at the light source and do not account for light lost from the fixture, while other fixtures meant to put light on a specific application (e.g. recessed downlights, under cabinet lights, accent lights, cove lights) are measured at the fixture level, only counting the light that escapes the fixture.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.
A distinguishing identifier, usually alphanumeric, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.

Measure of the degree of color shift objects undergo when illuminated by the light source as compared with the color of those same objects when illuminated by a reference source of comparable color temperature.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.

Most fixtures are designed to operate on an on/off switch. However, some fixtures have been designed with features to perform in specialized applications, such as with dimmers, three-way, or photo cell controls. Special features and compatibility with controls should be clearly marked on the product packaging, cut sheet or web site for the product.
The light source technology utilized by the fixture: compact fluorescent light (CFL), light emitting diode (LED), or halogen.
Ratio of real power flowing to the lamp to the apparent power in the circuit. A lamp with a lower power factor will draw more current than a lamp with a higher power factor of the same wattage.
Indicates if the unit includes a light source.

Fan motor electrical usage is the only energy consumption considered for the fan efficacy calculation. Energy used for other fan auxiliaries (e.g., lights, sensors, heaters, timers, or night lights) is not included in the determination of fan efficacy.
Residential bath and utility ventilating fans and range hoods must meet maximum allowable sound levels between 2-3 sones. There are no sound requirements for single or multi-port in-line fans.
The type of ventilating fan.

Indicates models meeting the Most Efficient criteria for 2019. The ENERGY STAR Most Efficient 2019 criteria recognizes the most efficient products among those that qualify for the ENERGY STAR. These exceptional products represent the leading edge in energy efficient products this year. For more information, please visit www.energystar.gov/mostefficient
Indicates information on certification relevant to the consumer (i.e. product variations, unique issues concerning the model’s listing, etc.).

Indoor/outdoor machines may be suitable for outdoor use or suitable for protected locations. Indoor machines are suitable for indoor use only (per UL Standard 541).

Refrigerated beverage vending machines are either Class A or Class B. Combination vending machines are either Combination A or Combination B. 'A' types have mostly transparent fronts; 'B' types have mostly opaque fronts. Combination machines may contain two or more compartments separated by a solid partition. For detailed definitions see the RBVM product specification.

The maximum quantity of standard product that can be dispensed from one full loading of the vending machine without further reload operations when used as recommended by the manufacturer (per ANSI/ASHRAE 32.1).

Vending machines eligible for ENERGY STAR may have a closed front door, glass front door, or live display front door.

Refrigerated volume represents the volume of the interior cabinet where cold beverages are stored as measured by 10 CFR Part 431 Subpart Q, Appendix B.

The photometric measure of the luminous intensity per unit area of light travelling in a given direction, expressed in candelas per square meter (cd/m^2). Luminance refers to the brightness settings of a display.
For ABC-enabled displays, this is the on-mode power drawn by the display in a room with bright ambient light.

The power mode the product enters after receiving a signal from a connected device or an internal stimulus. The product may also enter this mode by virtue of a signal produced by user input. The product must wake on receiving a signal from a connected device, a network, a remote control, and/or an internal stimulus. While the product is in this mode, it is not producing a visible picture, with the possible exception of user-oriented or protective functions such as product information or status displays, or sensor-based functions.

A computer monitor that has all of the following features and functionalities: (a) A contrast ratio of at least 60:1 measured at a horizontal viewing angle of at least 85° from the perpendicular on a flat screen or 83° on a curved screen, with or without a screen cover glass; (b) A native resolution greater than or equal to 2.3 megapixels (MP); and, (c) A color gamut 32.9% of CIE LUV.

The power mode in which the product is connected to a power source, and is not providing any On Mode or Sleep Mode functions. This mode may persist for an indefinite time. The product may only exit this mode by direct user actuation of a power switch or control. Some products may not have this mode.

The ability of the model to maintain connectivity on behalf of an end point device such as a personal computer that is in a sleep or other low power mode (LPM) thereby allowing for power savings in connected devices.
 a) Network Proxy - Base Capability: To maintain addresses and presence on the network while in LPM, the system handles IPv4 ARP and IPv6 NS/ND.
b) Network Proxy - Full Capability: While in LPM, the system supports Base Capability, Remote Wake, and Service Discovery/Name Services.
c) Network Proxy - Remote Wake: While in LPM, the system is capable of remotely waking upon request from outside the local network. Includes Base Capability.
d) Network Proxy - Service Discovery/Name Services: While in LPM, the system allows for advertising host services and network name. Includes Base Capability.

columns_description: Indicates information on certification relevant to the consumer (i.e. product variations, unique issues concerning the model’s listing, etc.).

Most fixtures are designed to operate on an on/off switch. However, some fixtures have been designed with features to perform in specialized applications, such as with dimmers, three-way, or photo cell controls. Special features and compatibility with controls should be clearly marked on the product packaging, cut sheet or web site for the product.

The amount of light emitted by the light source or light fixture. Non directional fixtures (with removable light sources i.e. GU24 base bulbs) are measured at the light source and do not account for light lost from the fixture, while other fixtures meant to put light on a specific application (e.g. recessed downlights, under cabinet lights, accent lights, cove lights) are measured at the fixture level, only counting the light that escapes the fixture.

Efficacy is calculated by using airflow and fan motor electrical power values as tested per the requirements of this specification. Fan motor electrical usage is the only energy consumption considered for the fan efficacy calculation. Energy used for other fan auxiliaries (e.g., lights, sensors, heaters, timers, or night lights) is not included in the determination of fan efficacy.

Efficacy is calculated by using airflow and fan motor electrical power values as tested per the requirements of this specification. Fan motor electrical usage is the only energy consumption considered for the fan efficacy calculation. Energy used for other fan auxiliaries (e.g., lights, sensors, heaters, timers, or night lights) is not included in the determination of fan efficacy.

It is standard industry practice to round down airflow to the nearest 10 cfm when publishing this metric in product directories as the Airflow Certified Rating. For this reason, Airflow Certified Rating and As-Tested Airflow may occasionally differ on this list. In the case of a range hood, Airflow Certified Rating represents performance at working speed, while in the case of a bathroom or utility room fan, or an in-line ventilating fan, it represents maximum speed.

Measure of the degree of color shift objects undergo when illuminated by the light source as compared with the color of those same objects when illuminated by a reference source of comparable color temperature.

A description of the "color" of a light source measured on the Kelvin (K) scale. CFLs are available in a range of color temperatures. Lower values (2700-3000K) mean the white light has a warmer (red-yellow) tone, while higher kelvin (4100-6500K) mean the white light has a cooler (bluer) tone.

The quotient of the total luminous flux (lumens) emitted by the fixture over the total power input (Watts). It is expressed in lumens per watt (lm/W). For ENERGY STAR qualified fixtures this applies to light fixtures that are considered directional and are measured at the fixture level. This includes the following residential grade directional fixture types: line-voltage track lights, ceiling fan light kits, undercabinet and cove lighting, downlights, recessed, pendant or surface mounted and includes retrofit kits for existing recessed cans. This also includes the following LIMITED commercial fixture types: Accent lights such as line-voltage track lights, under cabinet task lights, portable desk task lights, downlights, recessed, pendant or surface-mounts BUT EXCLUDES typical commercial and industrial fixtures such as recessed troffers or linear forms (e.g. linear fluorescent pendants) typically used in office spaces.

Desktop: A computer whose main unit is designed to be located in a permanent location, often on a desk or on the floor. Desktop computers are not designed for portability and are designed for use with an external display, keyboard, and mouse.

Integrated Computer: A desktop computer in which the computing hardware and display are integrated into a single housing, and which is connected to ac mains power through a single cable. Integrated desktop computers come in one of two possible forms: (1) a system where the display and computer are physically combined into a single unit; or (2) a system packaged as a single system where the display is separate but is connected to the main chassis by a dc power cord and both the computer and display are powered from a single power supply.

Notebook: A computer designed specifically for portability and to be operated for extended periods of time both with and without a direct connection to an ac mains power source.

Slate/tablet: A computing device designed for portability.

Portable All-in-one Computer: A computing device designed for limited portability.

Small-scale Server: A computer that typically uses desktop components in a desktop form factor, but is designed primarily to be a storage host for other computers. Small-scale Servers are designed to perform functions such as providing network infrastructure services (e.g., archiving) and hosting data/media.

Thin Client: An independently-powered computer that relies on a connection to remote computing resources to obtain primary functionality. Main computing functions (e.g., program execution, data storage, interaction with other Internet resources) are provided by the remote computing resources.

Workstation: A high-performance, single-user computer typically used for graphics, CAD, software development, financial and scientific applications among other compute intensive tasks.

have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information
on certified models in their information systems.

resource.name: Switzerland ENERGY STAR Certified Imaging Equipment
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 2.0 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Imaging Equipment that are effective as of January 1, 2014. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at https://www.energystar.gov/products/office_equipment/imaging_equipment/key_product_criteria
columns_name: If automatic duplex output capable, is duplexing shipped as the default?
columns_description: The date that the model is available for purchase.
Annualized TEC of the DFE.
The model number of the DFE. Again, the model number may be the same as or different from that of the Imaging Equipment product.
The power measured when a product enters Sleep Mode, either automatically after a period of inactivity, in response to user manual action, or in response to external electrical stimulus.
The maximum claimed monochrome speed in ipm (images per minute) and mppm (mail pieces per minute) when processing the given media.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of
seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification
information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will
have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information
on certified models in their information systems.
The average power of the DFE recorded while the main Imaging Equipment product is in Ready State.
The time between job initiation and first sheet exiting the Imaging Equipment product, with the measurement taken after the product has been in Sleep Mode for 1 hour.

The power measured when the product is in the lowest power consumption state which cannot be switched off by the user and that may persist for an indefinite time when the product is connected to the main electricity supply and used in accordance with the manufacturer’s instructions.

Typical electricity consumption (measured in kilowatt-hours) during normal operation over a specified period of time. Typical Electricity Consumption (TEC) is a method of testing and comparing the energy performance of certain imaging equipment products and focuses on the typical electricity consumed by a product while in normal operation during a representative period of time. The TEC metric is a proxy for a typical weekly electricity consumption. Please note: the TEC value should be used as a way to compare products' energy consumption values under a set duty cycle and operating conditions. Actual energy consumption will differ, based on how the product is used. TEC is not applicable to all imaging equipment products.
The marking technology of the product: direct thermal, dye sublimation, electro-photographic, impact, ink jet, high performance ink jet, solid ink, stencil, thermal transfer.
The ENERGY STAR Manufacturing Partner is the organization that has signed an ENERGY STAR Partnership Agreement and labels the model. This organization is typically the brand owner.
The time between job initiation and first sheet exiting the Imaging Equipment product, with the measurement taken after the product has been powered on and has indicated it is in Ready State.
The time between job initiation and first sheet exiting the Imaging Equipment product with the measurement taken 15 minutes after the start of a previous job.

The DFE Typical Electricity Consumption (TECDFE) metric assumes 9 hours in Ready State five days a week and the remainder in Sleep Mode. DFEs without a Sleep Mode are assumed to be in Ready State 168 hours per week.
The time set by the manufacturer prior to shipping that determines when the product will enter a lower-power Mode (e.g., Sleep, Auto-off) following completion of its primary function.

Whether or not a copier, fax machine, MFD, or printer has the capability to produce images on both sides of an output sheet, without manual manipulation of output as an intermediate step. A product is considered to have automatic duplexing capability only if all accessories needed to produce duplex output are included with the product upon shipment.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification
bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance
characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it
is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of
characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned
by EPA.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

1) Large Format: Products designed for A2 media and larger, including those designed to accommodate continuous-form media greater than or equal to 406 mm wide. Large-format products may also be capable of printing on standard-size or small-format media. 2) Standard Format: Products designed for standard-sized media (e.g., Letter, Legal, Ledger, A3, A4, B4), including those designed to accommodate continuous-form media between 210 mm and 406 mm wide. Standard-size products may also be capable of printing on small-format media. 3) Small Format: Products designed for media sizes smaller than those defined as Standard (e.g., A6, 4”x6”, microfilm), including those designed to accommodate continuous-form media less than 210 mm wide.

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.

A functional adder is a data and network interface or other feature that adds functionality to the marking engine of an imaging equipment product and provides a power allowance when qualifying products according to the OM method.
The average power of the DFE recorded while the main Imaging Equipment product is in Sleep Mode, applicable to DFEs with network-capable Sleep Modes.
Eligible product types include: printer, scanner, copier, fax machine, multifunction device, digital duplicator, or mailing machine.
A distinguishing identifier, usually alphanumeric, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler.
This list/dataset includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
Whether the product's output is monochrome (shades of black and white) or color.

resource.name: EU ENERGY STAR Certified Displays
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 6.0 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Displays that are effective as of June 1, 2013. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at https://www.energystar.gov/index.cfm?c=monitors.pr_crit_monitors.
columns_name: Is Automatic Brightness Control Enabled When Monitor/ Display is Shipped?
columns_description: The network connection used for the display.
The diagonal screen size in inches.
The 4 types of Displays eligible for ENERGY STAR certification are: Digital Picture Frame, Professional Display/Signage, Monitor, and Enhanced-Performance Display.
The lighting technology used to illuminate the panel. The most common types of backlight technology are LEDs and CCFLs.

The power mode in which the product is connected to a power source, and is not providing any On Mode or Sleep Mode functions. This mode may persist for an indefinite time. The product may only exit this mode by direct user actuation of a power switch or control. Some products may not have this mode.
A distinguishing identifier, usually alphanumeric, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification
bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance
characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it
is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of
characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned
by EPA.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.
The most common screen types include TN LCD, IPS LCD, VA LCD, OLED, Plasma, CRT, and others.
For ABC-enabled displays, this is the on-mode power consumed by the display in a room with bright ambient light.
The areal density of the luminous flux incident at a point on a surface. Illuminance refers to the ambient light conditions in the environment in which the display is located.

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.

The power mode in which the product has been activated, and is providing one or more of its principal functions. The common terms "active," "in-use," and "normal operation" also describe this mode. The power in this mode is typically greater than the power in Sleep Mode and Off Mode.
The peripheral port used for the display.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
This list/dataset includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.

A computer monitor that has all of the following features and functionalities: (a) A contrast ratio of at least 60:1 measured at a horizontal viewing angle of at least 85°, with or without a screen cover glass; (b) A native resolution greater than or equal to 2.3 megapixels (MP); and, (c) A color gamut size of at least sRGB as defined by IEC 61966 2-1. Shifts in color space are allowable as long as 99% or more of defined sRGB colors are supported.

The photometric measure of the luminous intensity per unit area of light travelling in a given direction, expressed in candelas per square meter (cd/m2). Luminance refers to the brightness settings of a display.
For ABC-enabled displays, this is the on-mode power consumed by the display in a room with low ambient light.

The power mode the product enters after receiving a signal from a connected device or an internal stimulus. The product may also enter this mode by virtue of a signal produced by user input. The product must wake on receiving a signal from a connected device, a network, a remote control, and/or an internal stimulus. While the product is in this mode, it is not producing a visible picture, with the possible exception of user-oriented or protective functions such as product information or status displays, or sensor-based functions.
The date that the model is available for purchase.
The maximum resolution that the device is capable of displaying.
The fixed physical pixel count of the display.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of
seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification
information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will
have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information
on certified models in their information systems.
The self-acting mechanism that controls the brightness of a display as a function of ambient light.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.

Indicates models meeting the Most Efficient criteria for 2016. The ENERGY STAR Most Efficient 2016 criteria recognizes the most efficient products among those that qualify for the ENERGY STAR. These exceptional products represent the leading edge in energy efficient products this year. For more information, please visit www.energystar.gov/mostefficient

columns_description:
The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of
seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification

An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. This column includes alternative means to identify the model/model family (e.g., additional model names, additional model numbers, retailer SKUs, product descriptions).
The sound transmission mechanism of the telephone, either analog, Voice over Internet Protocol (VoIP), or a hybrid of analog and VoIP.

The physical configuration of the telephone including: Cordless Telephone, a telephone with a base station and a handset; Corded Telephone, a telephone with a permanent physical connection between the handset and the network; Conference Telephone, a telephone without a handset that utilizes a speakerphone for all communications and is primarily used for conference calls; Additional Handset, a telephone designed for use with a multi-handset telephone system; or a Wireless (Wi-Fi) Telephone, a telephone that connects via Wi-Fi.
The number of additional handsets supported by the telephone.

Frequency ranges are used in cordless telephones primarily to allow for multiple devices to utilize the same ranges and to permit frequency-hopping by the phones. The term “frequency” refers to the rate at which an electromagnetic wave oscillates.

Mode with the telephone is connected to a power source and a telephone line or other physical or wireless network connection and is capable of receiving a call. The telephone is not receiving or transmitting sound, and the handset is "on the hook" and the speakerphone is not engaged.
The ability of a telephone to maintain network presence on behalf of an End Point Device.
Physical data ports on the model.
Low power wireless technologies supported by the model.
The number of Gigabit (10/100/1000) Ethernet ports present in the model.
The number of Fast (10/100) Ethernet ports present in the model.
A technology which enables reduced power consumption of Gigabit Ethernet interfaces during times of low data throughput. Specified by IEEE 802.3az.
A technology which enables reduced power consumption of Fast Ethernet interfaces during times of low data throughput. Specified by IEEE 802.3az.
The native resolution of the telephone's display.

The class of Power Over Ethernet indicating the range of operating power of the device. PoE is a technology which enables the transfer of electrical power, along with data, to network end point devices through an Ethernet cable.

A component contained in a separate physical enclosure external to the telephone casing, designed to convert line voltage ac input from the mains to lower dc voltage(s) in order to provide power to the telephone.
The date that the model is available for purchase.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.

characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned
by EPA.

AFUE: The Annual Fuel Utilization Efficiency ("AFUE") measures the amount of fuel converted to space heat in proportion to the amount of fuel entering the boiler. This is commonly expressed as a percentage. CAafue: The Combined Appliance Annual Fuel Utilization Efficiency (“CAafue”) is the effective efficiency of the combined appliance in performing the function of space heating.
Boiler product types include: Residential Boiler and Combination Space-Heating and Water Heating Appliance

resource.name: Upcoming ENERGY STAR Certified Residential Refrigerators
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 5.0 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Residential Refrigerators and Freezers that are effective as of September 15, 2014. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at http://www.energystar.gov/index.cfm?c=refrig.pr_crit_refrigerators
columns_name: Percent Less Energy Use than US Federal Standard
Meets ENERGY STAR Most Efficient 2019 Criteria
columns_description:
A unique string of characters assigned by certification
bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance
characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it
is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of
characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned
by EPA.
The date that the model is available for purchase.

This number is the estimated annual energy use in kilowatt hours of the refrigerator under typical conditions. Your actual energy consumption will vary depending on how you use your refrigerator, such as frequency of opening and closing, surrounding room temperature, and how full the unit is kept. This figure is calculated according to U.S. Department of Energy test procedures.

This is a figure accounting for the fact that freezers require more energy than refrigerators per unit of actual volume, because they are colder. The adjusted volume is the sum of the fresh food compartment volume and the product of an adjustment factor and the net freezer compartment volume in cubic feet. It's used to determine the federal energy conservation standards for refrigerators and freezers. Refrigerator Adjusted Volume = Fresh Volume + (1.63 x Freezer Volume). Freezer Adjusted Volume = 1.73 x Freezer Volume.
Measured from the floor to top of hinge.
This refrigerator design is approximately 24 inches deep without the door, making them nearly flush with standard kitchen cabinets. With the doors, they are generally 27-29 inches deep.
Designation for refrigerators, refrigerator-freezers, and freezers with a total volume of less than 7.75 cubic feet and 36 inches or less in height.

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.
A distinguishing identifier, usually alphanumeric, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
The U.S. federal standard is the maximum energy consumption in kWh/year allowed by the U.S. Department of Energy for a refrigerator of this particular configuration and size.
This is the type of defrost function. Automatic, manual, and partial automatic are the standard defrost types.
ENERGY STAR certified residential refrigerators must exceed the U.S. federal standard by at least 10%. This column tells you by how much each model exceeds the standard.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of
seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification
information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will
have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information
on certified models in their information systems.
The total interior volume of the refrigerator, including both the refrigerator and freezer compartments. Generally, the larger the refrigerator, the greater the energy consumption.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.

Indicates models meeting the Most Efficient criteria for 2019. The ENERGY STAR Most Efficient 2019 criteria recognizes the most efficient products among those that qualify for the ENERGY STAR. These exceptional products represent the leading edge in energy efficient products this year. For more information, please visit www.energystar.gov/mostefficient
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
Built-in refrigerators are designed to be installed totally encased by kitchen cabinets.
Allows access to ice and/or water through an exterior dispenser. Automatic icemakers and through the door dispensers offer convenience but they can increase energy use by 14-20%.
Measured from side to side.
Included in some refrigerators for making ice cubes.

Indicates whether the model offers advanced controls and increased functionality such as sending notifications when the refrigerator door doesn't close or allowing for a service center to remotely diagnose problems. Refrigerators with connected functionality are smart grid ready; if linked with your energy provider or an energy management system these products can dynamically adjust their energy use, potentially lowering your electric bill.
This shows the configuration of the refrigerator.

columns_description: An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.

This column includes alternative means to identify the model/model family (e.g., additional model names, additional model numbers, retailer SKUs, product descriptions).
The sound transmission mechanism of the telephone, either analog, Voice over Internet Protocol (VoIP), or a hybrid of analog and VoIP.

Frequency ranges are used in cordless telephones primarily to allow for multiple devices to utilize the same ranges and to permit frequency-hopping by the phones. The term “frequency” refers to the rate at which an electromagnetic wave oscillates.

Telephony products transmit data using one of two types of technologies: analog or digital. Analog phones rely on conventional radio waves that are modulated to carry sound to and from the handset. Digital phones transmit sound in two values, zeros and on

A communication technique whereby the carrier frequency of a signal is automatically and rapidly changed to provide enhanced transmission range, extendable portable numbers, and additional security. This definition includes direct sequence (e.g., digital)

The lowest power consumption mode which cannot be switched off. Standby mode is the condition in which a telephony product is connected to a power source and is inactive (i.e., the unit is not transmitting a conversation or recharging a low battery).

columns_description: The date that the model is available for purchase.
The average power of the DFE recorded while the main Imaging Equipment product is in Sleep Mode, applicable to DFEs with network-capable Sleep Modes.
The model number of the DFE. Again, the model number may be the same as or different from that of the Imaging Equipment product.
The power measured when a product enters Sleep Mode, either automatically after a period of inactivity, in response to user manual action, or in response to external electrical stimulus.

1) Large Format: Products designed for A2 media and larger, including those designed to accommodate continuous-form media greater than or equal to 406 mm wide. Large-format products may also be capable of printing on standard-size or small-format media. 2) Standard Format: Products designed for standard-sized media (e.g., Letter, Legal, Ledger, A3, A4, B4), including those designed to accommodate continuous-form media between 210 mm and 406 mm wide. Standard-size products may also be capable of printing on small-format media. 3) Small Format: Products designed for media sizes smaller than those defined as Standard (e.g., A6, 4”x6”, microfilm), including those designed to accommodate continuous-form media less than 210 mm wide.
The ENERGY STAR Manufacturing Partner is the organization that has signed an ENERGY STAR Partnership Agreement and labels the model. This organization is typically the brand owner.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of
seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification
information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will
have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information
on certified models in their information systems.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.

Typical electricity consumption (measured in kilowatt-hours) during normal operation over a specified period of time. Typical Electricity Consumption (TEC) is a method of testing and comparing the energy performance of certain imaging equipment products and focuses on the typical electricity consumed by a product while in normal operation during a representative period of time. The TEC metric is a proxy for a typical weekly electricity consumption. Please note: the TEC value should be used as a way to compare products' energy consumption values under a set duty cycle and operating conditions. Actual energy consumption will differ, based on how the product is used. TEC is not applicable to all imaging equipment products.

The time between job initiation and first sheet exiting the Imaging Equipment product, with the measurement taken after the product has been in Sleep Mode for 1 hour.

The power measured when the product is in the lowest power consumption state which cannot be switched off by the user and that may persist for an indefinite time when the product is connected to the main electricity supply and used in accordance with the manufacturer’s instructions.
The maximum claimed monochrome speed in ipm (images per minute) and mppm (mail pieces per minute) when processing the given media.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification
bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance
characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it
is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of

Annualized TEC of the DFE.
Whether the product's output is monochrome (shades of black and white) or color.
The time between job initiation and first sheet exiting the Imaging Equipment product with the measurement taken 15 minutes after the start of a previous job.

A functional adder is a data and network interface or other feature that adds functionality to the marking engine of an imaging equipment product and provides a power allowance when qualifying products according to the OM method.
The time set by the manufacturer prior to shipping that determines when the product will enter a lower-power Mode (e.g., Sleep, Auto-off) following completion of its primary function.
The time between job initiation and first sheet exiting the Imaging Equipment product, with the measurement taken after the product has been powered on and has indicated it is in Ready State.

Whether or not a copier, fax machine, MFD, or printer has the capability to produce images on both sides of an output sheet, without manual manipulation of output as an intermediate step. A product is considered to have automatic duplexing capability only if all accessories needed to produce duplex output are included with the product upon shipment.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

The DFE Typical Electricity Consumption (TECDFE) metric assumes 9 hours in Ready State five days a week and the remainder in Sleep Mode. DFEs without a Sleep Mode are assumed to be in Ready State 168 hours per week.
The marking technology of the product: direct thermal, dye sublimation, electro-photographic, impact, ink jet, high performance ink jet, solid ink, stencil, thermal transfer.
Eligible product types include: printer, scanner, copier, fax machine, multifunction device, digital duplicator, or mailing machine.
The average power of the DFE recorded while the main Imaging Equipment product is in Ready State.
A distinguishing identifier, usually alphanumeric, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler.

columns_description: The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.

The cycle selection and settings (temperature and dryness where separately selectable) as defined in the U.S. Department of Energy test procedure, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 10, Section 430, Subpart B, Appendix D2, Section 3.3, used for certification to ENERGY STAR.

The estimated energy test cycle time is the time taken to complete the test cycle necessary for ENERGY STAR certification. Products must complete the energy test cycle in less than 80 minutes in order to be certified as ENERGY STAR. The estimated test cycle time does not reflect actual consumer cycle times which vary as a result of load size, dampness, and composition.

This is the drum capacity of the clothes dryers in cubic feet as measured by the U.S. Department of Energy test procedure, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 10, Section 430, Subpart B, Appendix D2. Products with a drum capacity less than 4.4 cubic feet are considered compact.
A Universal Product Code (UPC) is a specific type of barcode for tracking items sold in stores.
A distinguishing identifier, usually alphanumeric, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information on certified models in their information systems.
Paired clothes washer ENERGY STAR Model Identifier .
The depth of the clothes dryer.
The date that the model is available for purchase.

Venting Configuration refers to how the clothes dryer exhausts heated air. Vented clothes dryers exhaust the evaporated moisture from the clothes dryer cabinet using a vent which typically leads to a building’s exterior. Ventless clothes dryers use a closed loop system with an internal condenser to remove the evaporated moisture from the heated air. Moisture is discharged from the cabinet and instead collected in a reservoir or drained through a tube.

Features applicable to the clothes dryer may include drum light, wrinkle prevention option, steam cycle, sanitization cycle, filter cleaning indicator, energy monitor/indicator, time remaining display, and supplementary drying system.
Provides guidance about what you need in your home to enable connected capabilities like smart phone control, e.g. ‘WiFi’ or Zigbee.
Open Standard - Application Layer include SEP 1.x, SEP2.x, OpenADR, etc.
This field is used to indicate the fuel type used to heat the air necessary to dry the clothes, either electric or gas.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
Indicates if the clothes dryer is being marketed as a matched pair with an ENERGY STAR Clothes Washer.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned by EPA.

The estimated annual energy use is based on the Combined Energy Factor and an annual usage of 283 cycles per year, as referenced by the U.S. Department of Energy test procedure, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 10, Section 430, Subpart B, Appendix D2. Actual energy consumption will vary on your usage patterns, including how often your run the dryer, what cycle you select, and load size. NOTE: For gas dryers the estimated annual energy use is expressed in kilowatt hours to allow for comparison, and represents the equivalent multi-source energy use of the product (e.g., natural gas or propane typically expressed in British thermal units (Btu)).

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.

Indicates models meeting the Most Efficient criteria for 2019. The ENERGY STAR Most Efficient 2019 criteria recognizes the most efficient products among those that qualify for the ENERGY STAR. These exceptional products represent the leading edge in energy efficient products this year. For more information, please visit www.energystar.gov/mostefficient

The Calculated CEF – Max Dry is a measure of the dryer’s energy performance in a more energy consumptive setting, namely the normal cycle with the highest dryness setting as defined in the ENERGY STAR Most Efficient 2017 criteria. The Calculated CEF – Max Dry should not be directly compared to the CEF field, which is tested using the medium dryness setting, and represents a rated rather than measured value. The CEF metric has units lbs/kWh and is calculated by dividing the weight of the test load by the sum of the per cycle standby and off mode energy consumption and either the total per-cycle electricity dryer energy consumption or the total per-cycle gas dryer energy consumption expressed in kilowatt hours (kWh).

Connected appliances may or may not enable open-standards connectivity in the home. Consider the following illustrative examples: "Yes" An appliance that can directly communicate using Wi-Fi and OpenADR, or wired Ethernet and SEP 2.x; "No" An appliance that uses proprietary communications to/from the cloud, and is capable of supporting open-standards communications only in the cloud.

Indicates whether the model offers advanced controls and increased functionality such as sending notifications when the dryer is done or allowing for a service center to remotely diagnose problems. Clothes dryers with connected functionality are smart grid ready; if linked with your energy provider or an energy management system these products can dynamically adjust their energy use, potentially lowering your electric bill.

CEF is the energy performance metric for ENERGY STAR clothes dryers; the higher the CEF the more efficient the clothes dryer. The metric has units lbs/kWh and is calculated by dividing the weight of the test load by the sum of the per cycle standby and off mode energy consumption and either the total per-cycle electricity dryer energy consumption or the total per-cycle gas dryer energy consumption expressed in kilowatt hours (kWh).
The height of the clothes dryer.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
The width of the clothes dryer.

bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance

by EPA.

An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
