A Modular UPS is comprised of two or more single UPS modules, sharing one or more common frames and a common energy storage system, whose outputs, in normal mode of operation, are connected to a common output bus contained entirely within the frame(s). Modular UPSs may be used to provide redundancy, to scale capacity or both. For qualification of a Modular UPS Product Family, both the minimum and maximum configuration models are tested.

The capability of an Ac-output UPS to operate in one or more Normal Modes classified by input dependency characteristic (ordered from highest to lowest input dependency): Voltage and Frequency Dependent (VFD): Capable of protecting the load from power outage Voltage Independent (VI): Capable of protecting the load as required for VFD, above, and in addition from under-voltage applied continuously to the input and over-voltage applied continuously to the input Voltage and Frequency Independent (VFI): Independent of voltage and frequency variations and capable of protecting the load against adverse effects from such variation without depleting the stored energy source. Input dependency characteristic is not applicable to Dc-output UPS/Rectifier models.

Multiple-normal-mode UPS: A UPS that functions in Normal Mode within the parameters of more than one set of input dependency characteristics. For example, a UPS that can function as either VFI or VFD.

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Residential Clothes Washers
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 6.1 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Clothes Washers that are effective as of February 1, 2013. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at http://www.energystar.gov/index.cfm?c=clotheswash.pr_crit_clothes_washers
columns_name: Meets ENERGY STAR Most Efficient 2015 Criteria
columns_description: Indicates models meeting the Most Efficient criteria for 2015. The ENERGY STAR Most Efficient 2015 criteria recognizes the most efficient products among those that qualify for the ENERGY STAR. These exceptional products represent the leading edge in energy efficient products this year. For more information, please visit www.energystar.gov/mostefficient

A unique string of characters used to identify models with the same performance characteristics. This sequence is generated by certification bodies and is reported as a single row of data on the lists of certified products.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.
The date that the model is available for purchase.

This is the estimated annual water use of the washer under typical conditions.
It is based on an annual usage of 392 loads per year, or around 8 loads per
week, as referenced by the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) test procedure,
Code of Federal Regulations, Title 10, Section 430, Appendix J1. Actual water
consumption will vary depending on the amount of laundry done.
The mandatory water efficiency standards for clothes washers, established by DOE rulemaking activities and federal laws.

WF is the water performance metric for ENERGY STAR certified clothes washers. The lower the WF, the more efficient the clothes washer. The metric
has units: gallons/cycle/ft3, and is calculated as the quotient of total weighted
per-cycle water consumption divided by the capacity of the clothes washer.
For example, if a clothes washer has a total weighted per-cycle water
consumption of 20 gallons and a tub volume of 4.0 cubic feet, then the water factor is 5.0.
Product ID
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
A distinguishing identifier, usually alphanumeric, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler.

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.
Type refers to whether the product is a front-loading washer or a top-loading washer.
This is the tub capacity of the clothes washer in cubic feet, as measured by the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) test procedure, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 10, Section 430, Appendix J1.

MEF is the energy performance metric for ENERGY STAR qualified clothes washers. The higher the MEF, the more efficient the clothes washer. The metric has units: ft3/kWh/cycle, and is calculated as the quotient of the capacity of the clothes container divided by the total clothes washer energy consumption per cycle. The total clothes washer energy consumption per cycle is the sum of the machine electrical energy consumption, the hot water energy consumption, and the energy required for removal of the remaining moisture in the wash load.
The mandatory energy efficiency standards for clothes washers, established by DOE rulemaking activities and federal laws.

This is the estimated annual energy use of the clothes washer under typical conditions, including the energy used by the washer and the energy needed to heat the water used by the clothes washer with an electric water heater. Unlike MEF, the estimated annual energy use does not address how effective the washer is at removing moisture from the wash load and thus reducing the
energy needed to fully dry a load in the clothes dryer. It is based on an annual
usage of 392 loads per year, or around 8 loads per week, as referenced by
the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) test procedure, Code of Federal
Regulations, Title 10, Section 430, Appendix J1. Actual energy consumption
will vary depending on various factors such as the amount of laundry done,
the size of the loads, and the settings chosen.
This refers to whether the product is intended to be sold in the residential market, the commercial/multi-family housing/coin laundry market, or both.

resource.name: Upcoming ENERGY STAR Certified Telephones
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 3.0 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Telephony (cordless telephones and VoIP telephones) that are effective as of October 1, 2014. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at http://www.energystar.gov/index.cfm?c=phones.pr_crit_phones
columns_description: The date that the model is available for purchase.

Mode with the telephone is connected to a power source and a telephone line or other physical or wireless network connection and is capable of receiving a call. The telephone is not receiving or transmitting sound, and the handset is "on the hook" and the speakerphone is not engaged.

The physical configuration of the telephone including: Cordless Telephone, a telephone with a base station and a handset; Corded Telephone, a telephone with a permanent physical connection between the handset and the network; Conference Telephone, a telephone without a handset that utilizes a speakerphone for all communications and is primarily used for conference calls; Additional Handset, a telephone designed for use with a multi-handset telephone system; or a Wireless (Wi-Fi) Telephone, a telephone that connects via Wi-Fi.

An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. This column includes alternative means to identify the model/model family (e.g., additional model names, additional model numbers, retailer SKUs, product descriptions).
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of
seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification
information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will
have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information
on certified models in their information systems.

A distinguishing identifier, usually alphanumeric, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler.
The sound transmission mechanism of the telephone, either analog, Voice over Internet Protocol (VoIP), or a hybrid of analog and VoIP.
A technology which enables reduced power consumption of Fast Ethernet interfaces during times of low data throughput. Specified by IEEE 802.3az.
The native resolution of the telephone's display.
Physical data ports on the model.
The number of Gigabit (10/100/1000) Ethernet ports present in the model.

Frequency ranges are used in cordless telephones primarily to allow for multiple devices to utilize the same ranges and to permit frequency-hopping by the phones. The term “frequency” refers to the rate at which an electromagnetic wave oscillates.

The class of Power Over Ethernet indicating the range of operating power of the device. PoE is a technology which enables the transfer of electrical power, along with data, to network end point devices through an Ethernet cable.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification
bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance
characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it

characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned
by EPA.
The number of additional handsets supported by the telephone.
A technology which enables reduced power consumption of Gigabit Ethernet interfaces during times of low data throughput. Specified by IEEE 802.3az.
The ability of a telephone to maintain network presence on behalf of an End Point Device.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
Low power wireless technologies supported by the model.

A component contained in a separate physical enclosure external to the telephone casing, designed to convert line voltage ac input from the mains to lower dc voltage(s) in order to provide power to the telephone.

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Commercial Clothes Washers
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 6.1 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Clothes Washers that are effective as of February 1, 2013. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at http://www.energystar.gov/index.cfm?c=clotheswash.pr_crit_clothes_washers
columns_description: The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.
A distinguishing identifier, usually alphanumeric, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler.

This is the estimated annual energy use of the clothes washer under typical conditions, including the energy used by the washer and the energy needed to heat the water used by the clothes washer with an electric water heater. Unlike MEF, the estimated annual energy use does not address how effective the washer is at removing moisture from the wash load and thus reducing the energy needed to fully dry a load in the clothes dryer. It is based on an annual usage of 1,074 loads per year for multi-family and 1,483 loads per year for laundromat applications, or around 21 and 29 loads per week respectively, as referenced by the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) test procedure, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 10, Section 430, Appendix J2. Actual energy consumption will vary depending on various factors such as the amount of laundry done, the size of the loads, and the settings chosen.
The date that the model is available for purchase.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

WF is the water performance metric for ENERGY STAR qualified clothes washers. The lower the WF, the more efficient the clothes washer. The metric has units: gallons/cycle/ft3, and is calculated as the quotient of total weighted per-cycle water consumption divided by the capacity of the clothes washer. For example, if a clothes washer has a total weighted per-cycle water consumption of 20 gallons and a tub volume of 4.0 cubic feet, then the water factor is 5.0.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of
seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification
information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will
have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information
on certified models in their information systems.
This refers to whether the product is intended to be sold in the residential market, the commercial/multi-family housing/coin laundry market, or both.

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a  product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.

MEF is the energy performance metric for ENERGY STAR certified commercial clothes washers. The higher the MEF, the more energy efficient the clothes washer. The metric has units: ft3/kWh/cycle, and is calculated as the quotient of the capacity of the clothes container divided by the total clothes washer energy consumption per cycle, with such energy consumption expressed as the sum of the machine electrical energy consumption, the hot water energy consumption, and the energy required for removal of the remaining moisture in the wash load. For example, if a clothes washer has a tub volume of 4.0 cubic feet and a total clothes washer energy consumption per cycle of 10 kWh/cycle, then the MEF is 2.5.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
This is the tub capacity of the clothes washer in cubic feet, as measured by the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) test procedure, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 10, Section 430, Appendix J2.
Type refers to whether the product is a front-loading washer or a top-loading washer.
The mandatory energy efficiency standards for clothes washers, established by DOE rulemaking activities and federal laws.

The 2 types of Displays eligible for ENERGY STAR certification are: Computer Monitors and Signage Displays. Referred to Product Type in the QPX requirements.
The most common screen types include TN LCD, IPS LCD, VA LCD, OLED, and Plasma. Referred to Display Type in the QPX requirements.
The lighting technology used to illuminate the panel. The most common types of backlight technology are LEDs and CCFLs.
The fixed physical pixel count of the display.
The diagonal screen size in inches.

Available methods of delivering power to the display.

The power mode in which the product has been activated, and is providing one or more of its principal functions. The common terms "active," "in-use," and "normal operation" also describe this mode. The power in this mode is typically greater than the power in Sleep Mode and Off Mode.

The power mode the product enters after receiving a signal from a connected device or an internal stimulus. The product may also enter this mode by virtue of a signal produced by user input. The product must wake on receiving a signal from a connected device, a network, a remote control, and/or an internal stimulus. While the product is in this mode, it is not producing a visible picture, with the possible exception of user-oriented or protective functions such as product information or status displays, or sensor-based functions.

The maximum On Mode power requirement for a Signage Display model with the given Screen Area and Maximum Reported Luminance to qualify for ENERGY STAR. The Power Consumption in On Mode cannot exceed this value. Computer Monitors must meet Total Energy Consumption Requirements.

The maximum Sleep Mode power requirement for a Signage Display model with the particular features to qualify for ENERGY STAR. The Power Consumption in Sleep Mode cannot exceed this value. Computer Monitors must meet Total Energy Consumption requirements.

The power mode in which the product is connected to a power source, and is not providing any On Mode or Sleep Mode functions. This mode may persist for an indefinite time. The product may only exit this mode by direct user actuation of a power switch or control. Some products may not have this mode.
For ABC-enabled displays, this is the on-mode power consumed by the display in a room with low ambient light.
Required if ABC is enabled by default and the model was tested at 230 volts. Indicate the 230 volt power consumption at 12 lux ambient light conditions (P12) in watts.
For ABC-enabled displays, this is the on-mode power drawn by the display in a room with bright ambient light.
Required if ABC is enabled by default and the model was tested at 230 volts. Indicate the 230 volt power consumption at 300 lux ambient light conditions (P300) in watts.

This calculation (for Computer Monitors only) assumes a daily duty cycle of 35% in On Mode and 65% hours in Sleep Mode over the course of a year. Signage Displays must meet On Mode, Sleep Mode, and Off Mode power requirements.
Required if the model is a Monitor and was tested at 115 volts. Provide the Total Energy Consumption at 230 volts based on test data in kilowatt-hours.

The maximum Total Energy Consumption requirement for a Computer Monitor model with the given Screen Area and Resolution to qualify for ENERGY STAR. The Total Energy Consumption cannot exceed this value. Signage Displays must meet On Mode, Sleep Mode, and Off Mode power requirements.

The photometric measure of the luminous intensity per unit area of light travelling in a given direction, expressed in candelas per square meter (cd/m^2). Luminance refers to the brightness settings of a display. Referred to Maximum Reported Luminance (cd/m^2)  in the QPX requirements

A computer monitor that has all of the following features and functionalities: (a) A contrast ratio of at least 60:1 measured at a horizontal viewing angle of at least 85° from the perpendicular on a flat screen or 83° on a curved screen, with or without a screen cover glass; (b) A native resolution greater than or equal to 2.3 megapixels (MP); and, (c) A color gamut 32.9% of CIE LUV.
The date that the model is available for purchase.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned by EPA.

Indicates models meeting the Most Efficient criteria for 2016. The ENERGY STAR Most Efficient 2016 criteria recognizes the most efficient products among those that qualify for the ENERGY STAR. These exceptional products represent the leading edge in energy efficient products this year. For more information, please visit www.energystar.gov/mostefficient

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Version 3.0 Enterprise Servers
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 3.0 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Enterprise Servers that are effective as of June 17, 2019. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at https://www.energystar.gov/products/office_equipment/enterprise_servers.

Memory scaling in Capacity is done through a scheme known as input data caching (IDC). Indicate the Capacity workload efficiency score for this configuration. These values reflect the updated SERT Version 1.1.0.

The Flood workload is based upon STREAM, a popular benchmark that measures memory bandwidth across four common and important array operations. Indicate the Flood workload efficiency score for this configuration. These values reflect the updated SERT Version 1.1.0.

Hashing and encryption/decryption are two pillars of modern computer security. The SHA-256 workload utilizes standard Java functions to perform SHA-256 transformations on a byte array. Indicate the SHA256 workload efficiency score for this configuration.

Sorting is one of the most common and important operations in computing. The SORT worklet sorts a randomized 64-bit integer array during each transaction. Indicate the SORT workload efficiency score for this configuration.

The power supply type can be either Single-output or Multi-output. A single-output power supply is a PSU that is designed to deliver the majority of its rated output power to one primary dc output for the purpose of powering a computer server. Single-output PSUs may offer one or more standby outputs that remain active whenever connected to an input power source. For purposes of this specification, the total rated power output from any additional PSU outputs that are not primary and standby outputs shall be no greater than 20 watts. A multi-output power supply is a PSU that is designed to deliver the majority of its rated output power to more than one primary dc output for the purpose of powering a computer server. Multi-output PSUs may offer one or more standby outputs that remain active whenever connected to an input power source. For purposes of this specification, the total rated power output from any additional PSU outputs that are not primary and standby outputs is greater than or equal to 20 watts.

A power supply unit (PSU) is a device that converts ac  input power to one or more dc power outputs for the purpose of powering a computer server. A computer server PSU must be self-contained and physically separable from the motherboard and must connect to the system via a removable or hard-wired electrical connection. A power supply unit can be installed explicitly for power redundancy in this configuration.
The number of rotational drives in this configuration.  A rotational drive is defined as a computer storage device which reads and writes to one or more rotating magnetic disk platters.
The memory capacity per dual in-line memory module, measured in GB, for this configuration.

The model or configuration number for the high-end performance configuration of the qualified product family. It is defined as the combination of Processor Socket Power, PSUs, Memory, Storage (HDD/SDD), and I/O devices that represents either the higher-price or higher-performance computing platform within the Product Family.

The model or configuration number for the typical or single configuration of the qualified product family. It is defined as a product configuration that lies between the Minimum and Maximum Power configurations and is representative of a deployed product with high volume sales.

The number of buffered double data rate (DDR) channels per Server/Blade/Node available in the configuration.  A buffered DDR channel is defined as a channel or Memory Port connecting a Memory Controller to a defined number of memory devices (e.g. DIMMs) in a computer server. A typical computer server may contain multiple Memory Controllers, which may in turn support one or more Buffered DDR Channels. As such, each Buffered DDR Channel serves only a fraction of the total addressable memory space in a computer server.

A computer server PSU must be self-contained and physically separable from the motherboard and must connect to the system via a removable or hard-wired electrical connection. A power supply unit can be installed explicitly for power redundancy in this configuration.
The memory capacity per dual in-line memory module, measured in GB, for this configuration.
The speed of the memory, measured in GHz, for this configuration.
The speed of the memory, measured in GHz, for this configuration.
The brand of the processor(s) installed in the product.
The number of processors installed in the product's as-shipped configuration.
The number of processors installed in the product's as-shipped configuration.
The available dual in-line memory modules.
If low power I/O states require the end user to enable them.
If low power I/O states are enabled in hardware upon shipment.
If processor dynamic frequency scaling capability is enabled in hardware upon shipment.
If processor power management is enabled in hardware upon shipment.
The manufacturer reported idle power value.
The types of power saving features that are enabled.
Types of operating systems supported by computer servers include Windows, Linux, Unix, Solaris, and SPARC.
Types of operating systems supported by computer servers include Windows, Linux, Unix, Solaris, and SPARC.
The number of expansion slots available for Input/Output (I/O) Devices and/or Auxiliary Processing Accelerators (APAs).
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

resource.name: Upcoming ENERGY STAR Certified Residential Freezers
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 5.0 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Residential Refrigerators and Freezers that are effective as of September 15, 2014. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at http://www.energystar.gov/index.cfm?c=refrig.pr_crit_refrigerators
columns_name: Percent Less Energy Use than US Federal Standard
columns_description: ENERGY STAR certified residential freezers must exceed the U.S. federal standard by at least 10%. This column tells you by how much each model exceeds the standard.
The U.S. federal standard is the maximum energy consumption in kWh/year allowed by the U.S. Department of Energy for a freezer of this particular configuration and size.

This number is the estimated annual energy use in kilowatt hours of the freezer under typical conditions. Your actual energy consumption will vary depending on how you use your freezer, such as frequency of opening and closing, surrounding room temperature, and how full the unit is kept. This figure is calculated according to U.S. Department of Energy test procedures.

This is a figure accounting for the fact that freezers require more energy than refrigerators per unit of actual volume, because they are colder. The adjusted volume is the sum of the fresh food compartment volume and the product of an adjustment factor and the net freezer compartment volume in cubic feet. It's used to determine the federal energy conservation standards for refrigerators and freezers. Refrigerator Adjusted Volume = Fresh Volume + (1.63 x Freezer Volume). Freezer Adjusted Volume = 1.73 x Freezer Volume.
The total interior volume of the freezer. Generally, the larger the freezer, the greater the energy consumption.

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.
A distinguishing identifier, usually alphanumeric, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of
seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification
information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will
have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information
on certified models in their information systems.
Built-in freezers are designed to be installed totally encased by kitchen cabinets.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification
bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance
characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it
is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of
characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned
by EPA.
The date that the model is available for purchase.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.
Included in some refrigerators for making ice cubes.

Freezers are available in both chest and upright configurations. An upright freezer has a front-mounted door like a refrigerator and shelves that allow for easy organization. A chest freezer typically requires more floor space, but they are also more energy efficient and since the door opens from the top it will allow less cold air to escape.

Indicates if the model has the through-the-door ice feature. It does not indicate whether or not the model has an ice maker. Please contact the manufacturer directly to determine if the model has an ice maker.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

Indicates whether the model offers advanced controls and increased functionality such as sending notifications when the freezer door doesn’t close or allowing for a service center to remotely diagnose problems. Freezers with connected functionality are smart grid ready; if linked with your energy provider or an energy management system these products can dynamically adjust their energy use, potentially lowering your electric bill.
Designation for freezers with a total volume of less than 7.75 cubic feet and 36 inches or less in height.

Freezers are available with either manual or automatic defrost. Manual defrost freezers use about half the energy of automatic defrost models, but must be defrosted periodically to achieve the energy savings. Don’t allow frost to build up more than one quarter of an inch.

domain_metadata.value: Climate Protection Program (Science & Technology, Environmental Programs & Management)

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Commercial Water Heaters
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 2.0 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Commercial Water Heaters that are effective as of  October 1, 2018. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at https://www.energystar.gov/products/water_heaters/commercial_water_heaters#specs.
columns_description:
A unique string of characters assigned by certification
bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance
characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it
is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of
characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned
by EPA.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.
The date that the model is available for purchase.
The average hourly energy, expressed in Btu/hr, required to maintain the stored water temperature.
Heat output refers to the useful heat transferred to the water, in thousand BTU per hour.
Height to vent is the distance from the bottom of the water heater's tank to its vent.
Tank height is the distance from the bottom of the water heater's tank to the top of its tank.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR certified products.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of
seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification
information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will
have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information
on certified models in their information systems.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
Input refers to the burner size of the gas-fired water heater, in thousand BTU per hour.
The type of vent used by the water heater: Atmospheric Vent, Direct Vent, or Power Vent.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
Vent size 2 is the width or diameter of a second vent opening.
The ratio of the heat transferred to the water flowing through the water heater to the amount of energy consumed by the water heater.
Tank diameter is the width or diameter of the water heater’s tank.

This column includes for the certified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a  product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.
Electric Input refers to the input wattage of the heat pump and ancillary electric components (e.g., fans, blowers, storage tank, piping, and controls).
The dimensionless ratio of the useful heat transfer gained by the water to the rate of electrical power consumed during full input rate operation.
The amount of water contained in the water heater measured in gallons. Some tankless water heaters do not have a storage volume.
A distinguishing identifier, usually alphanumeric, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler.
Vent size is the width or diameter of the vent opening.
This field is used to indicate the type of qualified product: Gas Storage Water Heater, Gas Storage-type Tankless Water Heater, Gas Tankless Water Heater, or Electric Heat Pump Water Heater.

All of these features are optional for ENERGY STAR Partners to report to EPA.
The four features include: Fault Detection and Display - the equipment reports, in plain text, system faults that have occurred; Performance Reporting - the equipment is capable of reporting at least three performance metrics such as fuel usage, hot water use, etc.; Energy Savings Reporting - the equipment is capable of analyzing performance to report potential energy savings opportunities to the user; Predictive Maintenance - the equipment is capable of tracking water heater use and wear rates to predict and alert the user of potential maintenance requirements.
Fuel type refers to the kind of fuel that the water heater uses to heat the water, either natural gas or propane for gas-fired water heaters, or electric for heat pump water heaters.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Certified Storm Windows
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 1.0 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Storm Windows that are effective as of September 5, 2018. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at https://www.energystar.gov/products/building_products/storm_windows_key_product_criteria.
columns_name: Thermal breaks for metal frame mounting included
columns_description: The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information on certified models in their information systems.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
A distinguishing identifier, usually alphanumeric, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler.

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.
Whether the product is an Exterior or Interior Storm Window product.

The storm window is only considered ENERGY STAR certified when installed in this climate zone. Climate zones share general climatic conditions, such as the number of heating days and cooling days, and are indicated by a shaded area on the ENERGY STAR storm window label.
How the window opens and closes.
The number of tracks of the storm window.
The material used for the frame of the storm window.
Is the frame painted or coated?
The material used for the window (generally glass, coated glass, or plastic).
Number of layers of glass or plastic used for the storm window. Most storm windows use one glazing layer.
The ability of the storm window to reflect heat inside instead of emitting outside. Emissivity ranges from 0 to 1, with a lower value reflecting more heat and being more efficient.

The amount of solar energy (heat) that passes through the storm window. Solar transmittance ranges from 0 to 1. Generally, higher solar transmittance values are preferable in colder climates and lower values are preferable in warmer climates.

The rate of air passing through the storm window when mounted over a calibrated panel, expressed in cubic feet per minute per square foot (cfm/ft2). Lower air leakage ratings mean that less air passes through the storm window.
Is a screen included in the standard version of this storm window model?
Amount of the total opening covered by the screen.
Feature that allows moisture to escape from between the storm window and primary window.
The storm window's moisture management system. Please note, a moisture management system is not required for ENERGY STAR certified interior storm windows.
Whether or not weather stripping is included with this product.
Whether or not thermal breaks for metal frame mounting is included with this product.
Whether or not the manufacturer offers a warranty for this product.
The length of the warranty period after purchase.
The date that the model is available for purchase.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.
This list/dataset includes products sold in the U.S..

A unique string of characters assigned by certification bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned by EPA.

resource.name: ENERGY STAR Most Efficient Ceiling Fans
resource.description: Please note, Ceiling Fan Light Kits are not included in this dataset. The Ceiling Fan Light Kit dataset can be found here: https://data.energystar.gov/Active-Specifications/ENERGY-STAR-Certified-Ceiling-Fans-Light-Kit/3zeh-haeu/data. Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 4.0 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Ceiling Fansthat are effective as of June 15, 2018. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at http://www.energystar.gov/index.cfm?c=ceiling_fans.pr_crit_ceiling_fans.
columns_name: Lighting Efficiency – Measured at the Source (lm/W)
Lighting Efficiency – Measured outside the Fixture (lm/W)
Meets ENERGY STAR Most Efficient 2019 Criteria
Special Lighting Features (Dimming, Motion Sensing, etc.)
columns_description: The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.

The amount of light emitted by the light source or light fixture. Fixtures (with removable light sources  are measured at the light source and do not account for light lost from the fixture, while other fixtures, where the light source cannot be removed, are measured at the fixture level, only counting the light that escapes the fixture. Ceiling fan light kits shipped with ENERGY STAR Lamps do not have to meet minimum light output requirements.
Power consumed by the fan when operating in standby mode, measured in Watts.
The measurement of the largest swept circle by any part of the fan blade assembly. In other words, the diameter of the ceiling fan.

This column includes for the certified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified certified products.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information on certified models in their information systems.

The ratio of the total airflow to the total power consumption, in units of cubic feet per minute per watt (CFM/W). For standard and hugger ceiling fans, this is a weighted efficiency based on the ceiling fan performance in low speed, high speed, and standby mode. For low-mount high-speed small-diameter ceiling fans, this is a weighted efficiency based on the ceiling fan performance in high speed and standby mode.
The date that the model is available for purchase.

The expected useful life of the light source. Measured differently depending on the technology of the light source. For example, LED lighting expected useful life is based on the estimated point at which only 70% of the original light output remains, while for older technologies, like fluorescent, estimated useful life is based on the measured median sample life.
Power consumed by the fan when operating at low speed, measured in Watts.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
Ratio of real power flowing to the lamp to the apparent power in the circuit. A lamp with a lower power factor will draw more current than a lamp with a higher power factor of the same wattage.
For ceiling fans with a light kit, this column indicates whether the ceiling fan is shipped with ENERGY STAR certified lamps
Power consumed by the fan when operating at high speed, measured in Watts.

A standard ceiling fan is a low-speed small-diameter ceiling fan that hangs greater than 10 inches from the ceiling. A low-mount HSSD ceiling fan is a high-speed small-diameter ceiling fan with a blade thickness greater than 1/8 inch that operates within safe blade tip speed limits. A hugger ceiling fan is a low-speed small-diameter ceiling fan that hangs less than or equal to 10 inches from the ceiling.
A distinguishing identifier, usually alphanumeric, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR certified products.
Proposed field definition: The quotient of the total luminous flux (lumens) emitted by the light source over the total power input (Watts). It is expressed in lumens per watt (lm/W).
Proposed field definition: The quotient of the total luminous flux (lumens) emitted by the fixture over the total power input (Watts). It is expressed in lumens per watt (lm/W).

Indicates whether the model offers advanced controls and increased functionality such as the ability to turn off the unit remotely when not at home and feedback on the energy use of the product. Connected functionality is optional and ceiling fans may be certified without it.
This column indicates whether the light kit is dimmable or not.
This list/dataset includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
This column indicates alternate ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) number(s) for the ENERGY STAR lamps that are shipped with the certified ceiling fan.
Total power consumed by the light kit (luminaire) while in use.

A description of the "color" of a light source measured on the Kelvin (K) scale. CFLs are available in a range of color temperatures. Lower values (2700-3000K) mean the white light has a warmer (red-yellow) tone, while higher kelvin (4100-6500K) mean the white light has a cooler (bluer) tone.
This column indicates the ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) number for the ENERGY STAR lamps that are shipped with the certified ceiling fan.
A distinguishing identifier, usually alphanumeric, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler. This model number pertains only to the lamp.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned by EPA.
Indicates information on certification relevant to the consumer (i.e. product variations, unique issues concerning the model’s listing, etc.).

Most fixtures are designed to operate on an on/off switch. However, some fixtures have been designed with features to perform in specialized applications, such as with dimmers, three-way, or photo cell controls. Special features and compatibility with controls should be clearly marked on the product packaging, cut sheet or web site for the product.

The Color Rendering Index (CRI) of a light source represents the degree of color shift objects undergo when illuminated by the light source as compared with the color of those same objects when illuminated by a reference source of comparable color temperature. The ENERGY STAR specifications require a CRI of at least 80. Incandescent lighting has a CRI of 100. Early fluorescent lighting had CRIs in the 60s, resulting in unpleasant appearance of skin tones.
The light source technology utilized by the fixture: compact fluorescent light (CFL) or light emitting diode (LED).
Certified ceiling fans shall provide a warranty of at least 3 years for all non-lighting components.

Certified ceiling fan light kits with replaceable drivers shall provide a warranty of at least 3 years. Certified ceiling fan light kits with non-replaceable drivers shall provide a warranty of at least 5 years.
Light sources can be fully integrated into a light kit or removable by a consumer by custom connectors, wire nuts, pronged plugs like GU10, GU24 or sockets e.g. E26 known as the Edison base.
This column indicates whether the ceiling fan is intended for indoor use only or can be used outdoors.
Provides guidance about what you need in your home to enable connected capabilities like smart phone control (e.g., Wi-Fi or ZigBee).
The number of light sources included in each light kit.
Additional sensors that may be built into a ceiling fan to provide added convenience and to increase energy savings.

resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 8.0 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Displays that came into effect on January 28, 2020.

Reported Contrast Ratio at -85 Degrees (Left) Horizontal Viewing Angle
Maximum Total Energy Consumption Limit for Monitor Certification (kWh/yr)
Maximum On Mode Power Limit for Signage Certification (watts)

columns_description: The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.
The number of Signage Display panels in the Maximum Tiled Configuration.
The rated or reported maximum power which the model can deliver via USB-C connection (W).
Does the model tested include a USB Type C port with Power Delivery capability?
Display contrast ratio at +85 degrees from the perpendicular, expressed as a integer relative to 1 (e.g., 1000 means 1000:1).
Display contrast ratio at -85 degrees from the perpendicular, expressed as a integer relative to 1 (e.g., 1000 means 1000:1).
The range of color supported within the CIE LUV 1976 u' v' color space and calculated per Section 5.18 Gamut Area of the Information Display Measurements Standard Version 1.03.

The maximum Total Energy Consumption requirement for a Computer Monitor model with the given Screen Area and Resolution to qualify for ENERGY STAR. The Total Energy Consumption cannot exceed this value. Signage Displays must meet On Mode, Sleep Mode, and Off Mode power requirements.

The power mode in which the product is connected to a power source, and is not providing any On Mode or Sleep Mode functions. This mode may persist for an indefinite time. The product may only exit this mode by direct user actuation of a power switch or control. Some products may not have this mode.

The maximum On Mode power requirement for a Signage Display model with the given Screen Area and Maximum Reported Luminance to qualify for ENERGY STAR. The Power Consumption in On Mode cannot exceed this value. Computer Monitors must meet Total Energy Consumption requirements.
Available methods of delivering content to the display.
The diagonal screen size in inches.
A distinguishing identifier, usually alphanumeric, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information on certified models in their information systems.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned by EPA.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
Display contrast ratio at 0 degrees from the perpendicular, expressed as a integer relative to 1 (e.g., 1000 means 1000:1).
A color space is a defined range of colors. Well known color spaces include sRGB, AdobeRGB and DCI-P3. Color spaces listed here are fully supported (100% of the defined range) by the Display.

A computer monitor that has all of the following features and functionalities: (a) A contrast ratio of at least 60:1 measured at a horizontal viewing angle of at least 85° from the perpendicular on a flat screen or 83° on a curved screen, with or without a screen cover glass; (b) A native resolution greater than or equal to 2.3 megapixels (MP); and, (c) A color gamut 32.9% of CIE LUV.
For ABC-enabled displays, this is the on-mode power drawn by the display in a room with bright ambient light.

The power mode in which the product has been activated, and is providing one or more of its principal functions. The common terms "active," "in-use," and "normal operation" also describe this mode. The power in this mode is typically greater than the power in Sleep Mode and Off Mode.
The fixed physical pixel count of the display.

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.
The date that the model is available for purchase.
For ABC-enabled displays, this is the on-mode power consumed by the display in a room with low ambient light.
Available methods of delivering power to the display.
The most common screen types include TN LCD, IPS LCD, VA LCD, OLED, and Plasma.

The HDR performance level for models that meet the VESA DisplayHDR CTS v1.0 Section 5.1 criteria. The model must meet the HDR performance level for all three white luminance criteria, including the 10% Center Patch Minimum Requirement (cd/m2), Full-screen Flash Minimum Requirement (cd/m2), and Full-screen Long-duration Minimum Requirement (cd/m2). N/A if the model does not meet the VESA DisplayHDR criteria.

The power mode the product enters after receiving a signal from a connected device or an internal stimulus. The product may also enter this mode by virtue of a signal produced by user input. The product must wake on receiving a signal from a connected device, a network, a remote control, and/or an internal stimulus. While the product is in this mode, it is not producing a visible picture, with the possible exception of user-oriented or protective functions such as product information or status displays, or sensor-based functions.

The photometric measure of the luminous intensity per unit area of light travelling in a given direction, expressed in candelas per square meter (cd/m^2). Luminance refers to the brightness settings of a display.

This calculation (for Computer Monitors only) assumes a daily duty cycle of 35% in On Mode and 65% hours in Sleep Mode over the course of a year. Signage Displays must meet On Mode, Sleep Mode, and Off Mode power requirements.
Features enabled in the default tested Sleep Mode.

The maximum Sleep Mode power requirement for a Signage Display model with the particular features to qualify for ENERGY STAR. The Power Consumption in Sleep Mode cannot exceed this value. Computer Monitors must meet Total Energy Consumption requirements.
The fixed physical pixel count of the display.
Is the Signage Display model tested as a Tiled Display System?
The 2 types of Displays eligible for ENERGY STAR certification are: Computer Monitors and Signage Displays.
Features enabled in the default tested On Mode.
The visible area of the Display that produces images.
Additional features and networking options available on the display.
Indicates models meeting the Most Efficient criteria for 2019.

resource.name: Grills
resource.description: Certified models meet all ENERGY STAR requirements as listed in the Version 1.1 ENERGY STAR Program Requirements for Commercial Griddles that are effective as of May 8, 2009 or January 1, 2011. A detailed listing of key efficiency criteria are available at http://www.energystar.gov/index.cfm?c=griddles.pr_crit_comm_griddles
columns_description: For gas griddles, this field expresses the rate of  griddle energy consumption while it is maintaining or holding at a stabilized operating condition or temperature. The idle rate is normalized based on the area of the (bottom) cooking surface.
The date that the model is available for purchase.
Designates the fuel type used by the commercial griddle. Qualified commercial griddle models are either gas or electric.

Designates the width of the griddle in ft. For qualification of a product family, the 3 ft. model within the product family can serve as the representative model. (If product family includes units smaller than 3 ft.; however, each additional unit shall be tested and qualified separately from its product family.)
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.
This column designates whether the model was tested in the single-sided or double-sided configuration.
This field provides additional details as to the type of griddle plate used (e.g., polished steel or chrome ½-inch grooved plate).
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.
Designates the depth of the griddle in ft.
The ratio of energy absorbed by the food product to the total energy supplied to the griddle during cooking.

The maximum production rate of the griddle while cooking a specified food product in accordance with the heavy-load cooking-energy efficiency test, expressed in pounds per hour. The production rate is the average rate at which the griddle brings a specified food product to a specified final temperature.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a  product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.

Designates whether the model is a single-sided or double-sided commercial griddle. A double-sided griddle has hinged upper griddle plates (platens) that swing down over the food, thereby cooking the food from both sides at once.
Represents the surface area of the commercial griddle (width multiplied by the depth).
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
A distinguishing identifier, usually alphanumeric, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler.

For electric griddles, this field expresses the rate of  griddle energy consumption while it is maintaining or holding at a stabilized operating condition or temperature. The idle rate is normalized based on the area of the (bottom) cooking surface.
This field demonstrates whether the product has integrated or add-on top platens. This impacts the testing of the models as single- or double-sided.

A unique string of characters assigned by certification
bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance
characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it
is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of
characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned
by EPA.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of
seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification
information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will
have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information
on certified models in their information systems.

columns_description:
A unique string of characters assigned by certification
bodies (CBs) to identify a model or set of models with the same performance
characteristics. This identifier should remain the same for a model even if it
is recertified to a new version of an ENERGY STAR specification. This string of
characters is determined by CBs and is not the ENERGY STAR Unique ID assigned
by EPA.
The light output per unit area when the television is in the Picture Setting that is ENERGY STAR qualified as shipped, expressed in units of candelas per square meter (cd/sq. meter).
The maximum On Mode power requirement for a model with the given Screen Area and Vertical Resolution to qualify for ENERGY STAR. The Power Consumption in On Mode cannot exceed this value.
An organization that signed a Partnership Agreement with EPA to manufacture or private label ENERGY STAR qualified products.

Standby Mode is the mode in which the TV is connected to a power source, produces neither sound nor picture, but can be switched into another mode. This field indicates the power in Standby-Passive Mode, for products without an active network connection. (TVs that have full network connectivity will not have data in this mode)
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.

The power mode in which the product is connected to a mains power source, produces neither sound nor picture, and is actively downloading data. Data downloads may include channel listing information for use by an electronic programming guide, TV setup data, channel map updates, firmware updates, monitoring for emergency messaging/communications or other network communications.

The ENERGY STAR Unique ID (ESUID) is a string of
seven numbers EPA assigns to an ENERGY STAR model or set of models with unique
performance characteristics. This ESUID is unique to both the model and product
specification version and is assigned by EPA upon receipt of certification
information from the certification body. Each row within the product list will
have a unique ESUID. Developers may wish to use this ESUID to track information
on certified models in their information systems.
Since this product category is no longer covered by ENERGY STAR Most Efficient, the field is no longer relevant and will contain no data.
This calculation assumes daily operation of 5 hours in On Mode and 19 hours in either Standby-Active, Low Mode (Standby Mode When Network Connected), if available, or Standby-Passive Mode.

Indicates whether the model has thin client capability, i.e., the ability to receive, decrypt, and display encrypted  content provided by a Multichannel Video Programming Distributor (MVPD) over the Local Area Network via a server device co-located on the customer premises without the need for a client device at the TV/HTD.
For products that were certified with Automatic Brightness Control (ABC) enabled, the names of those preset picture settings available on this TV that have ABC enabled, are listed here.
The features included with the TV.

On Mode is the power mode in which the product is connected to a mains power source, and is capable of producing dynamic video. For products with Automatic Brightness Control (ABC) enabled by default, this is the power measured when the television is exposed to 100 lux of ambient light is expressed in units of candelas per square meter (cd/sq. meter)

This column includes for the qualified model or family, family members, additional model names, model numbers and other identifying information associated with a  product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes. Other identifying information includes, but is not limited to, SKUs, UPC codes, retail numbers, and/or descriptions of models included/not included in the reported Model Family.
The backlight technology used in the TV.
The diagonal screen size in inches.

On Mode is the power mode in which the product is connected to a mains power source, and is capable of producing dynamic video. For products qualifying with Automatic Brightness Control (ABC) enabled by default, the reported On Mode Power is a weighted average of On Mode Power measured at ambient light levels of 3, 12, 35, and 100 lux. For products without ABC, the On Mode power is a measurement taken at an arbitrary light level.

On Mode is the power mode in which the product is connected to a mains power source, and is capable of producing dynamic video. For products with Automatic Brightness Control (ABC) enabled by default, this is the power measured when the television is exposed to 35 lux of ambient light is expressed in units of candelas per square meter (cd/sq. meter).
The self-acting mechanism that controls the brightness of a TV as a function of ambient light.
The wireless band and frequency supported by the model.

On Mode is the power mode in which the product is connected to a mains power source, and is capable of producing dynamic video. For products with Automatic Brightness Control (ABC) enabled by default, this is the power measured when the television is exposed to 12 lux of ambient light is expressed in units of candelas per square meter (cd/sq. meter).
A distinguishing identifier, usually alphanumeric, assigned to a product by the manufacturer or private labeler.
The physical pixel count for the vertical axis of the television (e.g., a television with a screen resolution of 1920 x 1080 (horizontal x vertical) would have a native vertical resolution of 1080).
The viewable screen area of the product, calculated by multiplying the viewable image width by the viewable image height.
Includes products sold in the U.S. and/or Canada and other ENERGY STAR partner countries.

A Television is a product designed to produce dynamic video. A TV contains an internal TV tuner
encased within the product housing and is capable of receiving dynamic visual content from
wired or wireless sources. 

Also included are Home Theater Displays (HTDs), which have screen size greater than 25
inches and do not contain an internal TV tuner.
The light output per unit area when the television is in the brightest selectable preset mode, expressed in units of candelas per square meter (cd/sq. meter).

The maximum Standby Mode power requirement to qualify for ENERGY STAR (does not depend on Screen Area). The Power Consumption in Standby Mode (Standby-Passive or Standby-Active, Low, whichever is applicable) cannot exceed this value.
The most common screen types include Liquid Crystal Display (LCD) screens, that are either LED direct-lit or LED edge-lit displays, or organic light-emitting diode (OLED).
An identifier assigned by the manufacturer or private labeler to a product or family/series of products for sales and marketing purposes.
For products that have an HDR Upscaling feature, the light output per unit area (when this feature is enabled) is expressed in units of candelas per square meter (cd/sq. meter).

For models with Automatic Brightness Control (ABC) enabled by default, the light output per unit area when the television is exposed to 100 lux of ambient light is expressed in units of candelas per square meter (cd/sq. meter).

For models with Automatic Brightness Control (ABC) enabled by default, the light output per unit area when the television is exposed to 3 lux of ambient light is expressed in units of candelas per square meter (cd/sq. meter).
For products that were certified with Automatic Brightness Control (ABC) enabled, the names of those preset picture settings available on this TV that do not have ABC enabled, are listed here.

On Mode is the power mode in which the product is connected to a mains power source, and is capable of producing dynamic video. For products with Automatic Brightness Control (ABC) enabled by default, this is the power measured when the television is exposed to 3 lux of ambient light is expressed in units of candelas per square meter (cd/sq. meter).
The self-acting mechanism that controls the brightness of a TV as a function of ambient light.
The horizontal by vertical pixel count of the TV.
The market for which the product is intended.
Network connections, usually using Internet Protocol (IP).

For models with Automatic Brightness Control (ABC) enabled by default, the light output per unit area  when the television is exposed to 12 lux of ambient light is expressed in units of candelas per square meter (cd/sq. meter).

Standby mode is the mode in which the TV is connected to a power source, produces neither sound nor picture, but can be switched into another mode. This field indicates the power in Standby-Active, Low Mode, for products with an active network connection. (TVs that do not have full network connectivity will not have data in this mode)
For products that have a High Dynamic Range (HDR) Upscaling feature, this is the measured power with that feature enabled.
The date on which the product was confirmed to meet the ENERGY STAR specification.

For models with Automatic Brightness Control (ABC) enabled by default, the light output per unit area when the television is exposed to 35 lux of ambient light is expressed in units of candelas per square meter (cd/sq. meter).
Indicates which energy saving features are enabled for this product.
The date that the model is available for purchase.
